title: Can anyone be a DJ? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on your definition of a DJ. If it simply means a person who plays music for others, sure (no mixing involved). Anyone with a pulse and mp3s can do it. If you’re asking about being a real, professional working DJ, then the answer is definitely a resounding NO. Here’s why: A real working DJ takes time to master their mixing craft (like years), music selection, reading the crowd, keeping up with new music, practices, also does branding and promotions, and basically works very hard for peanuts- especially in the beginning of their DJ career. After years of struggles and lots of practice, a DJ can get better, and also get better gigs once their reputation is built. Even then, you deal with shady promoters, hate from fellow DJs trying to bring you down (because of insecurity about their own ability), and a myriad of other difficulties. It is not easy… Hopefully IF you built a good rep, you will start getting lots of repeat business over time, and possibly DJ full-time for higher pay (weddings, parties, corporate gigs, clubs, etc. etc.).

Sure. Just Bluetooth your phone to a boom box at a party & press play on your Spotify playlist and voila! You're a DJ. Now whether that makes you a good DJ, that people want to listen to or have at their party or not, is something else entirely. The proliferation of DJ apps over the past 15 or so years has really changed the industry dramatically. Whilst they've lowered the barriers to entry, the apps have convinced a lot of people that it's easier than it actually is. Many of the challenging aspects have been automated with algorithms - particularly in respect to beatmixing & transitions. Everything's seamless & perfect. Zero skill needed - simply let the app do everything for you and sound like a star. Kinda sounds appealing, doesn't it? Minimal effort with maximal results. You can almost hear the crowds chanting your name at festivals. Jet setting celebrity. All from an app. Except it doesn't work that way. At all. Technology can't replace talent. Now don't get me wrong. DJs only exist because of technology. After all, DJs were born from a tech revolution. Radio jocks resulted from the birth of the medium. And things pretty much stayed that way for decades, with DJs never rising much past being a voice tha accompanied your favourite tunes, filling the gaps between them. It was about personality, more than anything else. And then the revolution happened. A little hi fi company called Technics, released a turntable with radical features like direct drive and variable pitch control. DJing as we know it today, owes everything, and I mean EVERYTHING, to the 1200. Pioneers in Detroit, Chicago, New York & elsewhere realized how powerful a tool it was. Beatmixing was born, sounds were bent, remixing & sampling could be done live in the club. The DJ as a performer in his own right was now a reality. Then came hip hop & rap, where the DJ took the place of the traditional band, creating a sonic backdrop for the MCs to spit bars over. Technology, once again revolutionized things with the CD. It took a bit for the hardware to evolve to the point where a DJ could perform somewhat the same as he would on vinyl. The release of the Pioneer CDJ-1000, followed by mp3s, laptops & interfaces, coded vinyl & CDs, really allowed DJs to become superstar performers - headliners, in their own right. Something to aspire to. Now, the reason I've gone through this very condensed, abridged history of DJing is to point something out. Until the advent of these new DJ apps which automate everything, in order to be a DJ, you had to be able to mix, among other things. There was skill involved. Talent was needed. Pressing play didn't make you a DJ, flow did (among other things). The good news is that the skills required to DJ can be learned. From simple beatmixing through more complex transitions to flow & vibe and even more abstract aspects like ear (not your biological hearing apparatus but rather the intangible quality of critical listening), everything can be learned & developed. Then there's the type of gig, which also affects things. For example, weddings & parties are vastly different than pubs & clubs, which are again different from concerts or festivals. Weddings & parties focus less on beatmixing & more on overall flow. The DJ is there to augment the event rather than be the focus. A deep library and knowledge of music is more important because of the diversity of the crowd. The deeper your musical knowledge here, the easier it is to keep the flow going. Crash fading Garth Brooks into Slipknot into Frankie Goes to Hollywood into Frank Sinatra results in a shit gig. You can begin to specialize a bit spinning in pubs, which are kind of halfway between parties & clubs. At a club, the DJ is the entertainment, so here is where you get to specialize your format and show off your skills. Here, as well as pubs, your flow is as important as your mixing. The top club DJs understand how to keep the crowd rotating with the flow. They cycle the crowd from dancefloor to bar to seating/sidelines and back to the floor. Concerts are where you get to shine, whether you're opening or headlining. This is where you get to show off what you do. All your tricks, your sound, your vibe. This is typically what people think of when they think of DJs. Here it's all about the dancefloor. Behind the decks, it's all yours and you are god. Beatmixing, transitions, sonic tricks, etc, all come to the forefront. Your style & flow is what people are here for. Of course, you may be wondering why I'm mentioning this breakdown. Simple. The skills you need to be a successful DJ vary depending on where you are. Again, these skills can all be learned, though some are more difficult to master than others. To wrap it all up, it is absolutely possible to teach anyone to be a legit DJ. The concepts involved are, for the most part, straightforward. Making a living at it, on the other hand, not so much. Especially if your goal is to be a world famous headliner. Anyway, I've rambled on long enough, cheers.

Well..: okay, let’s go through this. If one is both deaf and blind, then they may have a difficult time of it though technically they could do it (not very well, but it’s possible). If a person is deaf and blind and is missing both their hands and feet, then it would be perhaps possible to hit the play and cue buttons with one’s nose ..: so again difficult but possible. If one were completely paralyzed, deaf, blind, and were missing both their arms and feet, then it would be very very difficult… i would say next to impossible without extra assistance. However, djs get assistants all of the time to do things like carry records or maybe even throw on a song while the DJ uses the restroom. I remember that once Madonna “DJed” but she really just sort of stood there wearing headphone while her assistant did all of the work selecting, cueing, and playing songs. In this theoretical case, a very very strong “DJ assistant” could hypothetically lift up the paralyzed, deaf, mute, no arm or leg having DJ and use the djs nose to push the buttons and trigger different effects. So there you have it. Anybody can be a DJ! Thanks, great question!

That question is probably best answered by reframing your question slightly… to “can anyone be a good DJ” With todays technology and availability of music and endless track lists of big name dj’s anyone can become a Dj. My two children who are 8 and 9 can play music they like and perform tremendous feats of finger dexterity. But are they DJ’s? No they aren’t. The fact they can perform a mix on equipment that does everything for them doesn’t make them dj’s. To become a “good” Dj takes time, practice, endless hours of learning from your performance, being able to play to a dance floor of people and hold them there over the course of an evening, which in itself can’t be done by just anyone. In summary, can anyone be a Dj? Yes. Can anyone be a good Dj? No because the learning curve knocks out the people not committed to learning the trade.

Used to be, anyone could be a DJ with years of practice, collecting the best albums, and good technique and a sense of music. Now, anyone can be a DJ as long as they have enough money to buy a shitty controller and some bluetooth speakers. It used to take dedication and skill to be a DJ. Now people think that producing a few shitty progressive house tracks and playing them through a Numark Party Mix to their light - up Bluetooth speaker makes them a DJ. Hope that answers your question.

Anyone can “Be a DJ" but it's a different thing when you want to be a great DJ that gets booked for gigs. In 1997 when I started we didn't have laptops or CDJs that tells u the BPM. You had to learn to Beatmatch etc…. All own your own. Now you can spend $600-$800 and call your self a DJ but there is so much more to DJ'n than standing behind some decks just to try and pick up chicks. JS.

Yes definitely! As long as you put time and effort to learn the basics, and money for the proper DJ equipment, anyone can become a professional DJ that makes a proper living out of it. Skills, techniques, and gear that famous DJs use are now accessible to everyone. Check How To Become a Professional DJ and you will see that even advanced DJ tools and skills are easy to learn and get. The DJ world is also very friendly to beginners, as you can find softwares, tutorials, promo tracks, totally free to get you going without spending a dime.Cheers…

Yes! I am a self taught DJ. I started out of curiosity and learnt the basics using a free version of Virtual DJ. My interest kept growing and I decided to take it to the next level by purchasing a DJ controller. One thing for sure, learning never stops. I keep learning new skills by simply practicing. Oh, I almost forgot! You will have to listen to a wide range of music genres, and own a good music library. A good DJ should know their music.

YES . I believe anyone has the aptitude and ability to learn the technical aspects of djing. There are some things that will make someone better than others.. a sense of rhythm and timing.. understanding the structure of the style of music you’re playing, and ability to read a crowd’s reaction are all things that are necessary in varying degrees . Some people will catch on better than others . It helps to be around others with more experience as you I’ll learn much better

Anyone can call themselves a DJ. Being an actual DJ requires skill. You must put work into it to become a true DJ. There are people who use electronics to play music and call themselves a DJ, they are not. Example of a real DJ.

Well, yes and no. Nowadays it is easier and cheaper than ever to become a “bedroom dj” and potentially start a dj career. There are many excellent dj softwares such us VirtualDJ that will let you start mixing and learning with no extra cost. And even dj controllers are affordable. That would require a lot of money back in the analog days. Now, be a successful dj and professional is another story and depends entirely on you.

Anyone…and I mean anyone. If you have a passion for music and can learning these three things: beat matching, crowd control skills and be very knowledgeable with music….You can be a DJ. Realistically you can be good if you practice for 6months to a year. Sooner if you practice everyday!

Sure, if they put the time and effort into doing it. Being a DJ is not simply pressing ‘play’, as many non DJs seem to think. You also have to decide what type of DJ you wanna be, what style of music. Do you want to spin on turntables, DVS, controller, CDJ, etc??? Do you want to learn to beat match or beat juggle, or just straight DJ without the “fancy tricks"? As long as you're willing to work at it, you can become a DJ.
Yes. Anyone that has ever chosen to play music to another person is a DJ. However as a profession you need to be paid to do it.
Anyone CAN be a DJ. Not everyone is a GOOD DJ. Or soccer player, or government official.
